title: Afghan election challenger warns of dire consequences if polls marred by fraud
text:
Afghan presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah arrives for an interview in Kabul on Sept. 26, 2019. (Mohammad Ismail/Reuters)

The main challenger to Afghan President Ashraf Ghani in Saturday’s election said Thursday that a fraud-marred result “will be contested” and that his supporters would not be willing to “sacrifice” a legitimate victory at the polls.

Abdullah Abdullah, Afghanistan’s chief executive, did not say what he would do if massive fraud takes place, but he suggested in an interview that it would be up to Ghani to “act responsibly.”

“The results will not be accepted if there is clear evidence of fraud,” Abdullah said at his residence. “The signs are not good. . . . It is not an ideal situation for the country,” he added, referring to warnings by opposition groups and leaders, including himself, that Ghani and his government will try to rig the polls.

The tense election is being held under tight security; more than 2,400 of 7,400 polling centers are to remain closed because Taliban insurgents have threatened to attack them. The group has already bombed one Ghani campaign rally, killing 24 people, as well as the office of his top running mate, killing 30 others. The insurgent group has denounced the election as fake.

The Taliban renewed its threats Thursday, calling the election a foreign “sham” and calling on “freedom-loving Afghans” to boycott the polls. In an online statement, the group said it would close all roads in the country on election day and would target “all offices and centers that operate for this staged show.”

[Elections in Afghanistan: What you need to know]

But concerns about fraud are equally high among the public and observers because it could trigger political chaos. This nearly occurred in the 2014 presidential election, in which Ghani and Abdullah were also the top two contenders.

In the 2014 race, complaints of fraud were so widespread on both sides that the process collapsed amid threats of violence by armed political factions. Finally, after a failed recount, U.S. officials brokered an uneasy power-sharing agreement between the two rivals, an arrangement that has proved dysfunctional and embittered.

This time, there are 16 other candidates in the race, but few have campaigned seriously. Ghani, 70, who has run a vigorous and expensive campaign, is expected to win in a first round with more than 50 percent of the vote. But opponents have accused the president of vote-buying and other pre-election abuses, which he and his spokesmen have denied.

Abdullah, 59, has campaigned largely by attacking Ghani as a remote and self-centered leader who has deceived and disappointed the public. He has depicted himself as a more honorable politician who has twice agreed to concede an election for the good of the nation, first in 2009 in a close and fraud-plagued race against then-President Hamid Karzai, and then in 2014 against Ghani.

“The people who are supporting me, from the grass roots to the top, they say that this time somebody else should make sacrifices,” Abdullah said in the interview.



Abdullah Abdullah walks to a helicopter with Ustad Abdul Karim Khalili (right) heading to a final campaign rally in Bamiyan, Afghanistan, on Sept. 25, 2019. (Paula Bronstein/Getty Images)

At a boisterous final rally here Wednesday, Abdullah seemed buoyed after a week of cross-country campaigning. He made wisecracks about Ghani, describing the scholarly president as an “ant without wings,” then turned serious and called on supporters to “say no to fraud and use your clean vote to restore the country’s honor.”

A more relaxed and informal campaigner than Ghani, Abdullah has had a longer history and higher profile in Afghan public life. He was a senior aide to Ahmed Shah Massoud, the legendary anti-Soviet and anti-Taliban militia leader, whose portraits and photographs are prominently displayed in Abdullah’s home. (Massoud was assassinated in northern Afghanistan by al-Qaeda operatives posing as journalists two days before the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.) After the fall of the Taliban in November 2001, Abdullah served as foreign minister under Karzai.

Critics of Abdullah say that his anti-Ghani jokes and tirades are a substitute for his lack of a meaningful message or agenda on crucial national issues, especially on how to launch peace talks with the Taliban after the collapse of U.S. negotiations, and how to bolster the Afghan economy, which has sagged badly during the protracted civil conflict, leaving millions of Afghans jobless.

They also say he has relied too heavily on political support from ethnic ex-militia leaders, belying his moderate political and professional image. In 2014, he was backed by Attah Mohammed Noor, a powerful Tajik leader who threatened mass protests if Abdullah was not declared the winner. This time, he is counting on support from Abdurrashid Dostum, a tough Uzbek militia commander accused of serious crimes, and Mohammad Mohaqiq, an ethnic Hazara strongman.

“For Abdullah, this all goes back to 2014,” said Haroun Mir, a longtime political analyst who is now advising the Ghani campaign. “There is no substance in his campaign, only personal attacks. His goal is to remain relevant in politics, but his narrative is divisive, when the country needs unity.”



A massive crowd attends the final campaign rally for Abdullah Abdullah in Bamiyan, Afghanistan, on Sept. 25, 2019. (Paula Bronstein/Getty Images)

In the interview, Abdullah said Ghani has been “an obstacle towards peace,” because he wants to “remain at the top” of the process and keep all others in subordinate roles. “His self-centered sentiment overrides anything else,” Abdullah said. One difference between them is that “I want peace” he added. “If that means I will leave the office in order to achieve it, that will not be an obstacle.”

Abdullah has said he would support the creation of an interim government after the election if that would help create a national consensus and bring the Taliban into negotiations.

Speaking briefly about the economy, he said Ghani has offered too many “grand ideas” without focusing on more mundane public problems, especially unemployment. One key, he said, is to boost the private sector instead of “killing it,” by providing better access to loans, land and electricity, as well as controlling fraud.

But Abdullah’s mind Thursday was clearly on the more immediate issues confronting him and the nation in the next week, with millions of Afghans preparing to vote in an election that might be marred by fraud as well as violence — and the choice of how to respond resting in large part on him.

“I do worry,” he said. “I know that it’s not good for the country” if the election goes bad and the results are clouded. Asked what would happen in that case, he hesitated for a moment and added: “Why not leave it for that moment to decide? But it will not be accepted.”
